title: Toward Generative AI–Driven Metadata Modeling: A Human–Large Language Model Collaborative Approach
abstract: Abstract: For decades, the modeling of metadata has been core to the functioning of any academic library. Metadata’s importance has only increased with the pervasiveness of generative artificial intelligence–driven information activities and services. However, several challenges impact a library metadata model’s reusability, crosswalk, and interoperability with other metadata models. This paper posits that these problems stem from an underlying assumption that there should be only a few core metadata models that would be sufficient for any information service using them, irrespective of the heterogeneity of intradomain or interdomain settings. To that end, this paper advances a contrary view and substantiates its argument in three key steps. First, the paper introduces a novel way of thinking about a library metadata model as an ontology-driven composition of five functionally interlinked representation levels from perception to definition via properties. Second, the paper introduces the representational manifoldness implicit in each of the five levels, which cumulatively contributes to a conceptually entangled library metadata model. Finally, and most importantly, the paper proposes a generative AI–driven, human–large language model collaboration-based metadata modeling approach to disentangle the entanglement inherent in each representation level, which would lead to a conceptually disentangled metadata model. Throughout the paper, the author provides motivating scenarios and examples from libraries handling cancer information.

Toward Generative AI–Driven Metadata  
Modeling: A Human–Large Language Model 
Collaborative Approach
Mayukh Bagchi
LIBRARY TRENDS, Vol. 73, No. 3, 2025 (“Generative AI and Libraries: Applications and 
Ethics, Part I,” edited by Melissa A. Wong), pp. 297–322. © 2025 The Board of Trustees, 
University of Illinois
Abstract
For decades, the modeling of metadata has been core to the function-
ing of any academic library. Metadata’s importance has only increased 
with the pervasiveness of generative artificial intelligence–driven in-
formation activities and services. However, several challenges impact 
a library metadata model’s reusability, crosswalk, and interoperability 
with other metadata models. This paper posits that these problems 
stem from an underlying assumption that there should be only a few 
core metadata models that would be sufficient for any information 
service using them, irrespective of the heterogeneity of intradomain 
or interdomain settings. To that end, this paper advances a contrary 
view and substantiates its argument in three key steps. First, the paper 
introduces a novel way of thinking about a library metadata model 
as an ontology-driven composition of five functionally interlinked 
representation levels from perception to definition via properties. 
Second, the paper introduces the representational manifoldness 
implicit in each of the five levels, which cumulatively contributes to 
a conceptually entangled library metadata model. Finally, and most im-
portantly, the paper proposes a generative AI–driven, human–large 
language model collaboration-based metadata modeling approach 
to disentangle the entanglement inherent in each representation 
level, which would lead to a conceptually disentangled metadata model. 
Throughout the paper, the author provides motivating scenarios and 
examples from libraries handling cancer information.
[91.100.61.210]   Project MUSE (2025-11-05 17:26 GMT)
298 library trends/february 2025
Keywords
generative AI, metadata, ontology-driven metadata models, aca-
demic libraries, large language models, human-LLM collaboration, 
knowledge organization, knowledge representation
Introduction
Since the 1980s (Yu and Breivold 2008) and increasingly from the 
2000s (Tedd and Large 2004), the development and continual manage-
ment of (digitized) metadata has been core to the functioning of any 
well-administered academic library (Satija et al. 2020). With the advent 
and increasing pervasiveness of generative AI (Banh and Strobel 2023; 
Cox et al. 2019), the scope of an academic library has expanded to include 
the deployment of AI-based, data-driven information services such as re-
search data management (Andrikopoulou et al. 2022), ontology-driven 
content management (Bagchi 2021a, 2021b), and chatbots (Bagchi 2020), 
all of which depend on a well-founded metadata model semantically an-
notating and exposing underlying data. For instance, let us consider the 
scenario of semantically annotating scientific information in cancer re-
search (e.g., cancer big data [Jiang et al. 2022]) within the framework of 
an academic library. Such an exercise is clearly dependent on a multitude 
of factors, such as the purpose of the information, the target user base, 
technical features, and so on, each of which helps define the informa-
tion service that will harness the information. Thus, a metadata model 
designed for a specialized cancer research library would be significantly, if 
not completely, different from one designed for an oncology policy library 
(Han and Hswe 2011). These models might, again, be considerably differ-
ent from a metadata model employed by a medical college library.
This paper argues that, as evidenced from the motivating scenario and 
several other similar use cases (e.g., Gartner 2016; Ulrich et al. 2022; van 
Dijck 2014), there is no unique metadata model that is necessary and suf-
ficient for semantic data annotation within a single domain and certainly 
not for the heterogeneity inherent in cross-domain use case scenarios (see 
also EU-NSF Working Group on Metadata, n.d.). Through the lens of the 
motivating scenario, the paper elucidates the interlinked representation levels 
that cumulatively constitute a metadata model as indicated in the above 
thesis. First, the perception of the (expert) users of a cancer research library 
toward cancer research data would be highly specialized (e.g., uncover -
ing multi-omics workflows [Ulrich et al. 2022]) and hence considerably 
different to how the same data is perceived by the (expert) users of an 
oncology policy library or a medical college library. Second, as a partial 
consequence of the first reason, the terminology employed by the users of 
the three types of libraries would also be different. Third, the decision to 
ontologically characterize a perceived data concept as, for example, a func-
tion or a process (Arp and Smith 2008), or an object property or a data 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 299
property (Bagchi 2022a), would be different for each user group. Fourth, 
as a direct consequence of the ontological characterization, the taxonomy 
assumed by the users of the three types of libraries would be markedly 
different (Bagchi and Madalli 2019). Fifth, the characterization of the tax-
onomy in terms of interrelating and describing its constituent concepts via 
object properties and data properties would differ. Finally, it is also key to 
note that in the ordered representation levels, each level independently as 
well as cumulatively compounds the design of a metadata model created 
by one library and complicates its crosswalk with metadata models created 
by other libraries.
The contextualization of this motivating scenario into a general the-
sis about modeling metadata is not by chance. It is a direct instantiation 
of the problem of Conceptual Entanglement (Bagchi and Das 2022, 2023), 
ubiquitous in knowledge organization and representation research, which 
posits that any conceptual knowledge model (e.g., a metadata model) is 
representationally manifold by design and cannot be necessary and sufficient 
for all use cases irrespective of its intradomain or interdomain setting.
First, there is always a many-to-many correspondence (hereafter re-
ferred to as representational manifoldness) between entities and how they 
are perceived as concepts (e.g., by sets of users of the three different librar-
ies). Second, given perception, there is always a representational mani-
foldness between the perceived concepts and how they are linguistically 
labeled (e.g., by the same sets of users) using some terminology. Third, 
given labeling, there is always a representational manifoldness between 
the labeled concepts and their ontological status (e.g., by the same sets 
of users). Fourth, as a consequence of the manifoldness in ontological 
characterization, there is always a representational manifoldness between 
the ontologically characterized concepts and how they ought to be taxo-
nomically classified (e.g., as per the warrant of the same set of users). Fifth, 
there is always a representational manifoldness between the taxonomi-
cally classified concepts and how they are interrelated and described via 
properties.
This leads to two observations. First, it is interesting to note how the 
individual and cumulative impact of the representation layers magnifies 
the entanglement in the final metadata model. Second, and perhaps most 
importantly, there is a need to explicate the decision of the modeler (e.g., a 
metadata librarian) at each level, which, in an overwhelming majority of 
cases, remains implicit (Bagchi and Das 2022, 2023).
The solution proposed in this paper is a generative AI–driven, large 
language model (LLM)–based enhancement of an early version of the 
approach termed Conceptual Disentanglement (Bagchi and Das 2022, 2023). 
The key focus of this approach is to explicitly disentangle the decisions made 
by the modeler (e.g., a metadata librarian), at each knowledge represen-
tation level, which would otherwise implicitly entangle the final conceptual 
300 library trends/february 2025
knowledge artifact (e.g., the metadata model). To that end, the general 
strategy of the approach is to explicitly enforce one-to-one correspondence 
(hereafter referred to as representational bijection) out of the potentially 
many representational manifold possibilities at each level. To explain us-
ing the motivating scenario, first, the metadata librarian (who is the mod-
eler) should explicate a representational bijection between entities and 
their consensual perception as concepts (e.g., by a particular set of users of 
a library). Second, given the fixation of perception, the metadata librarian 
should explicate a representational bijection between the perceived con-
cepts and their linguistic labeling via a consensual body of terminology. 
Third, given the fixation of terminology, the metadata librarian should ex-
plicate a representational bijection between the labeled concepts and their 
ontological commitments (Guarino et al. 1994)—in other words, whether 
they are events, processes, or properties. In fact, an ontology-driven meta-
data model is key to encode precise semantics represented within (meta)
data concepts and properties (see, e.g., the arguments advanced in Dutta 
2014; Leipzig et al. 2021). Fourth, the metadata librarian should expli-
cate a representational bijection between the ontologically characterized 
concepts and their exact taxonomy. Fifth, given the taxonomy, the meta-
data librarian should explicate a representational bijection between each 
concept in the taxonomy and their exact definition via properties. Finally, 
it is interesting to note how the individual as well as the cumulative disen-
tanglement of the representation layers minimizes the entanglement in 
the final metadata model. The decision of the modeler should be explicit 
at each representation level, thereby crucially impacting the minimization 
of the conceptual entanglement.
While the contextualization, problem, and solution approaches are 
clear to some extent, it is not yet clear as to how the solution approach 
can be potentially implemented by a metadata librarian. In fact, two criti-
cal complementary highlights should characterize any implementation 
strategy of the conceptual disentanglement approach for modeling library 
metadata. First, while the approach attempts to disentangle, level by level, 
the entanglement inherent by design in a metadata model, it runs the 
risk of considerable intellectual work on the part of the metadata librar -
ian in terms of manually factoring and refactoring the constituent knowl-
edge management nitty-gritty (Bagchi 2019, 2022b). On the other hand, 
given the justified complexity of the conceptual disentanglement ap-
proach (e.g., in layers such as perception or ontology), an overtly (semi)
automatic implementation is not poised to produce an ontology-driven 
metadata model of requisite quality. To harness the best of both worlds 
(i.e., human and machine), the paper proposes a novel implementation 
of the conceptual disentanglement approach via generative AI–driven, 
human-LLM collaboration, where the metadata librarian, using prompt 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 301
engineering (Ekin 2023), exploits an LLM (Chang et al. 2024; Liang et al. 
2022) to generate a conceptually (dis)entangled metadata model that, for 
each representational level, is validated/repaired/enriched by the librar -
ian. The validation, repair, or enrichment of the human-LLM collabora-
tively generated metadata model can involve several standard dimensions. 
For metadata librarians, these dimensions could include metadata qual-
ity (Park 2009), semantic quality (Poels et al. 2005), and purpose-specific 
dimensions such as metadata model fitness for cancer data/information. 
Overall, a widespread acceptance and implementation of the conceptual 
disentanglement approach via generative AI–driven human-LLM col-
laboration is poised to bring to the fore several advantages in terms of 
metadata development methodologies, metadata crosswalk and interop-
erability (Khoo and Hall 2010), semantic heterogeneity (Hull 1997), and 
FAIR data (Wilkinson et al. 2016).
The remainder of the paper is organized as follows: The second section 
describes the different knowledge representation levels involved in designing a 
metadata model and how such levels are ordered and interlinked to cumu-
latively impact its design. The third section details the problem of concep-
tual entanglement individually and cumulatively across the representation 
levels and their confounding impact on the design of the metadata model. 
The fourth section elucidates the generative AI–driven human-LLM 
collaboration-based conceptual disentanglement approach and the way 
it minimizes the entanglement and confusion in the design of the meta-
data model. Finally, the fifth section discusses research implications from 
the related work in terms of some of the generative AI, metadata, and 
semantics-based research issues academic libraries face. Throughout the 
paper, an adapted instantiation of the motivating scenario of a simplified 
ontology-driven metadata model for cancer information will be employed 
to exemplify and highlight the issues and approaches. Given the method-
ological scope of the paper, several technical intricacies, for example, of 
knowledge representation, are not addressed.
As part of the research for this paper, three variations of an ontology- 
driven library metadata model for the cancer domain (e.g., encoding con-
cepts such as clinical trial, patient, biomarker, imaging test, histopathology 
report) were generated by ChatGPT 3.5 through a series of prompts (avail-
able for readers to review at Bagchi 2024). While these metadata models 
are informal in nature, this is not relevant to the scope of this paper, as 
similar models could be formalized in any language of choice (e.g., the 
web ontology language) for concrete implementation purposes.
Representation Levels in Modeling Metadata
This section of the paper expands the discussion on the characteristi-
cally independent but functionally interlinked knowledge organization and 
[91.100.61.210]   Project MUSE (2025-11-05 17:26 GMT)
302 library trends/february 2025
representation levels that cumulatively compose any metadata model 
within the framework of an academic library. To that end, we have the 
following levels:
1. Perceptual level, wherein the correspondence between entities and their 
perception as concepts is modeled;
2. Terminological level, wherein the correspondence between perceived 
concepts and the terms that linguistically represent them is modeled;
3. Ontological level, wherein the correspondence between labeled concepts 
and their ontological commitment is modeled;
4. Taxonomical level, wherein the correspondence between ontologically 
enriched concepts and their classification into a taxonomic hierarchy 
is modeled;
5. Definitional level, wherein the correspondence between the taxonomic 
concepts and how they are interrelated and described via properties is 
modeled.
The perceptual level, while not explicitly pronounced in state-of-the-art 
library metadata research and implementation (see, e.g., Haynes 2018; 
Strecker et al. 2021), is the very first level to achieve the crucial repre-
sentational choice as to how a set of entities should be perceived as con-
cepts (later) composing a library metadata model. Two key dimensions 
should inform the decision-making of a metadata librarian at this level. 
First, perception is highly egocentric to an individual academic library user 
and therefore is usually incomplete (Das et al. 2023) and cannot be fully 
captured in a (semi)formal manner. Second, it is also the case that various 
communities of practice (Cox 2005; Wenger 1999), such as users of different 
types of libraries, commit to a shared perception for how certain entities 
should be perceived as concepts.
Consider the case of the motivating example and the metadata models 
generated using ChatGPT. First, the author was able to use ChatGPT 3.5 
to generate a general (ontology-driven) library metadata model for the 
cancer domain with constituent concepts (classes and properties) at three 
levels of abstraction (Bagchi 2024, 1–7). Next, the general model, via suc-
cessive prompts, was tuned to the potential perceptions of a representa-
tive library user belonging to the specialized cancer research community 
(Bagchi 2024, 8–10), oncology policy community (Bagchi 2024, 10–12), 
and medical college student community (Bagchi 2024, 12–14). It is inter-
esting to observe that even for the same macro domain (i.e., cancer), each 
of the three metadata models encodes concepts and properties uniquely 
relevant to the perception of a specific user community.
Second, given the understanding as to why perception is crucial for 
modeling metadata, let us now turn to the terminological level, where the 
key representational choice is to decide how a set of perceived concepts 
should be labeled using a body of terminology. This choice is not trivial 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 303
for the metadata librarian due to the very nature of the interaction of 
language with the perceptual level. Languages are “itemized [terminologi-
cal] inventories” (Brown and Lenneberg 1954) of the entities we perceive, 
and each of such inventories generates either similar (but not the same) 
or different lexicalizations of the perception due to linguistic relativity 
(Boroditsky 2011). Such a lexicalization might manifest among different 
sets of academic library users in terms of different linguistic phenomena. 
For example, two well-known linguistic phenomena include polysemy, 
the coexistence of several potential meanings of a term, and synonymy, 
terms having similar meanings (Glynn and Robinson 2014). Lexical gaps 
(Bentivogli and Pianta 2000) occur when a specific language/vocabulary 
does not have a referent term for a concept. The scenario might get even 
more confounded when library user communities communicate with each 
other or with the computer system by linguistically referring to the per -
ceived entities with terms from specialized terminological standards (Su-
onuuti 1997) or glossaries (Sarginson et al. 2012), possibly from different 
languages. There might be issues with both mapping and interoperability 
of terms among the standards due to issues of linguistic phenomena or 
nonexistent terminological crosswalks. In the motivating example, the au-
thor prompted ChatGPT 3.5 to clarify the terminology employed in the 
three examples (Bagchi 2024, 20–23). Notice that parts of the cancer re-
search library metadata model use terms from the Dublin Core (Weibel et 
al. 1998) to express its perceived concepts. Similarly, the oncology policy 
library and the medical college library metadata models use terms from 
standards such as Health Level 7, the National Comprehensive Cancer 
Network, and the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine–Clinical Terms 
(Schulz et al. 2019).
Third, given the central importance of terminology in the design of any 
library metadata model, the next dimension to understand is the ontologi-
cal level, where the key representational choice regarding the ontologi-
cal commitment (Guarino et al. 1994) of the (newly) labeled concepts is 
made. This choice, again, is significant for the metadata librarian due to 
the theoretical root of the interaction of ontology with the terminological 
level, in the sense that committing to a terminology results in committing 
to an ontology (Moltmann 2019) that might not be necessarily completely 
compatible with another ontology/terminology pairing. The chief im-
portance of this representation level is to explicate the otherwise implicit 
commitment of the body of terms to a top-level ontology (Guarino 1997), 
wherein such an ontology, based on an explicitly specified philosophical 
doctrine, reveals the underlying nature of domain-level concepts. There 
can be several such philosophical doctrines, such as three-dimensionalism, 
four-dimensionalism, and so on (McCall and Lowe 2006), and according 
to the chosen doctrine, the domain-level labeled “concepts” can be classi-
fied as a kind, a part-of, an event, a process, a role, a function, or a property 
304 library trends/february 2025
(Gangemi et al. 2001). This representation layer is the most demanding 
in terms of the involvement of the human modeler, such as a metadata 
librarian, for the simple reason that while different library user communi-
ties might conceptualize the same set of entities into different top-level 
ontological categories, it is chiefly the responsibility of the metadata li-
brarian to explicate such assumptions. Second, as evidenced in decades 
of research in semantic heterogeneity (Hull 1997), the ontological level 
is key to achieving a range of semantics-intensive tasks such as semantic 
mapping (Beneventano et al. 2008) and semantic interoperability (Bittner 
et al. 2006) with respect to (meta)data models. In the motivating example, 
the author used ChatGPT 3.5 to elicit the LLM response to the prompt re-
questing the ontological categories employed in the three examples (Bag-
chi 2024, 23–29). For example, the LLM response aligns concepts and 
properties such as “document” and has “author” to top-level ontological 
categories such as “information object” and “quality” (Bagchi 2024, 26).
Fourth, given the importance of the ontological commitment of con-
stituent concepts and properties in a library metadata model, let us con-
centrate on the taxonomical level, where the key representational choice 
regarding the ontologically characterized concepts and their classification 
into a taxonomical hierarchy is made (see figure 1 for a quick glimpse). 
This choice by the metadata librarian is guided by two key factors. First, 
the ontological level already induces a very abstract, high-level taxonomy 
for the concepts due to the mandatory ontological constraints (Guarino 
et al. 1994) they pose, while the metadata librarian commits to a specific 
top-level ontology and its constituent top-level ontological categories. For 
example, if the concepts “person” and “patient” belong to the top-level 
ontological categories “kind” and “role,” it is an ontological constraint 
that “role” can never be the taxonomical parent of a “kind,” and, there-
fore, “patient” can never be the taxonomical parent of “person.” Within 
the ontological constraints, however, the taxonomy can be designed by 
the metadata librarian in accordance with how its hierarchy and meta-
data properties will be exploited by the target information service (e.g., a 
data catalog [Guptill 1999] or a chatbot [Bagchi 2020]). In the motivat-
ing example, the author used ChatGPT 3.5 to elicit the LLM response 
to the prompt requesting the taxonomical choices made for concepts as 
well as properties (Bagchi 2024, 23–29). For example, on page 30, “li-
brary resource” is specialized into “research paper” and “dataset.” Notice 
that, alongside the ontological level, the taxonomical level is also equally 
demanding, if not more, in terms of the involvement of the metadata librar-
ian in modeling the classification hierarchy.
Last but not the least, given the key importance of the taxonomic clas-
sification in the composition of a library metadata model, let us focus 
on the definitional level, where the key representational choice is how to 
interrelate and describe each individual concept in the taxonomy (see 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 305
figures 2 and 3 for a quick glimpse). This is done by first finalizing the 
specialization of the already classified properties at the ontological level 
into object properties and data properties (Bagchi and Madalli 2019). 
Note that even if the properties are informally classified as object or data 
property by the metadata librarian before this level, the final decision is 
taken at this level. Second, each concept in the taxonomy is assigned with 
a set of object properties that encode how the concept is interlinked with 
other concepts in the overall metadata model. Equally, and perhaps most 
importantly, every taxonomic concept is assigned a set of data properties 
that describe its attributes. This level is perhaps the most visible and pro-
nounced level in a library metadata model when it comes to implementa-
tion, as it decides on the data properties that ultimately encode real-world 
library metadata. Also, this level is central to a library metadata model in 
the sense that it decides the inheritance of data properties by classes (also 
known as concepts) in the taxonomy, thereby considerably influencing 
the decision concerning the description of each taxonomic concept by a 
set of data properties and data types. In the motivating example, the au-
thor used ChatGPT 3.5 to elicit the LLM response to the prompt request-
ing the object and data property choices made (Bagchi 2024, 34–39). For 
example, the concept “policy document” is described with data properties 
such as {policyDocumentID, policyDocumentTitle, policyDocumentText} 
(Bagchi 2024, 35).
Figure 1. Taxonomical hierarchies for (a) a cancer research library, (b) an oncology 
policy library, and (c) a medical college library.

306 library trends/february 2025
Figure 2. Object property hierarchies for (a) a cancer research library, (b) an oncology policy library, and (c) a medical college library.
Figure 3. Data property hierarchies for (a) a cancer research library, (b) an oncology policy library, and (c) a medical college library.
 metadata modeling / bagchi 307
Finally, it is interesting to note two crucial points about the aforemen-
tioned levels of knowledge organization and representation that consti-
tute any library or even a generic metadata model. First, the ordering 
from perception to definition via properties is not just a linear, ordered 
sequence but is essentially an ordered and continual interlinked scientific 
spiral (Ranganathan 1957). To that end, successive cycles can be utilized 
by the metadata librarian to continuously validate, repair, update, and en-
rich the library metadata model with changes in any of the representation 
levels. This also reinforces the notion of the nonvalidity of a single or a 
few metadata models as necessary and sufficient for any and every domain 
and application scenario. Second, notice that the above levels of repre-
sentation are a general framework to understand the composition of a 
library metadata model. It might well be the case that for a specific applica-
tion scenario, the perceptual level or the terminological level or both are 
quite homogeneous and, therefore, of much less relative importance to 
the model than the ontological level or the definitional level. In any case, 
such permutations and combinations of the relative importance of each 
representation level to the final library metadata model should be decided 
on a case-by-case basis.
Entanglement in Modeling Metadata
Given the central and irreplaceable impact of the five functionally inter -
linked representation levels on the modeling of metadata, let us now focus 
on how the conceptual entanglement problem is implicitly instantiated at 
each successive level within the metadata design strategy of an academic 
library. To that end, the entanglement levels mirror the representation 
levels:
1. Perceptual entanglement, referring to the representational manifoldness 
between entities and their perception as concepts;
2. Terminological entanglement, referring to the representational mani-
foldness between perceived concepts and the terms that are employed 
to label them;
3. Ontological entanglement, referring to the representational manifold-
ness between labeled concepts and their ontological commitment;
4. Taxonomical entanglement, referring to the representational manifold-
ness between ontologically enriched concepts and their taxonomic clas-
sification;
5. Definitional entanglement, referring to the representational manifold-
ness between the taxonomic concepts and their definition via properties.
In order to exemplify the stratification above, the same motivating ex-
ample of the ontology-driven library metadata model for the cancer do-
main is employed (Bagchi 2024, 8–43). Notice that the stratification of 
conceptual entanglement proposed above is in sync with the stratification 
308 library trends/february 2025
of representation in metadata proposed in the second section. The above 
levels are elucidated as follows.
Perceptual entanglement refers to the many-to-many mapping between 
entities and their perception as concepts that would eventually compose 
a library metadata model. Two key factors underlie the entanglement in 
the decision-making of a metadata librarian at this level. First, as already 
briefed before, perception is egocentric and can be unique to communi-
ties of practice. This premise leads to the notion of perception as a cog-
nitive filter (Guarino et al. 2020), in other words, in our terms, the fact 
that the same entity and its properties can be perceived differently by dif-
ferent groups of library users depending on their overall purpose and 
goals. There can be an overlap in the concepts perceived between, say, 
two groups of library users, and, equally, there can be ranges of mutual 
exclusion in their perception (e.g., due to different purposes or goals). 
Second, the highly implicit nature and consideration of perception within 
academic library metadata design (see, e.g., Fleming et al. 2008; Lopatin 
2010) almost leads to the necessary and sufficient assumption (explained 
before) on the surface while the underlying multiplicities of perception 
remain unaddressed. Consider the case of the motivating example gener-
ated by ChatGPT 3.5 via human-LLM collaboration. Three different user 
perceptions, namely, of a representative cancer research library (Bagchi 
2024, 8–10), an oncology policy library (Bagchi 2024, 10–12), and a medi-
cal college library (Bagchi 2024, 12–14) of the same macro domain, can-
cer, are illustrated in the example. Notice that the commonality in the 
perception of the three different communities is indicated by their shared 
perceived concept of cancer specialized by its various types (breast cancer, 
lung cancer, etc.) and described by common properties (e.g., biomarkers 
associated with a cancer). However, major differences emerge in the three 
perceptions due to their very purpose in studying the same entity. The 
cancer research library user community is interested in concepts such as 
research study types, treatments, and other properties, for example, the 
clinical trial ID and pathology report text. The oncology policy library 
user community, on the other hand, is interested in policy documents 
such as clinical guidelines, best practices, regulatory policy, and so on. 
The medical college library user community is interested in medical study, 
study material, treatment approach, and so forth. The full transcript pro-
vides more details on differences in perception (Bagchi 2024, 15–18). It is 
interesting to notice the representational manifoldness between the same 
(domain) entities and how they are variously perceived as concepts.
Second, let us focus on the terminological entanglement that implies 
the necessary existence of a many-to-many mapping between perceived 
concepts and their lexicalization using a terminological label. As briefly 
mentioned earlier, linguistic phenomena are a key inducer of representa-
tional manifoldness at this level. For example, polysemous terms labeling 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 309
a perceived concept provide at best an ambiguous notion of its meaning 
and magnify the many-to-many possibilities for the metadata librarian. On 
the other hand, the central problem with synonyms is the establishment 
of mapping. Given implicitly synonymous terms, it might not always be 
straightforward for the metadata librarian to infer whether they are the 
same or synonymous or a broader/narrower/distinct term. The above 
problems are further compounded in settings that involve multiple lan-
guages and/or multiple communities of different genres of academic li-
brary users. To exemplify, in the motivating example, let us consider the 
singular case of the concept “breast cancer” (Bagchi 2024, 8). It can be 
termed variously by different communities of library users as carcinoma 
of the breast, mammary carcinoma, breast tissue malignant neoplasm, or 
lobular adenocarcinoma. In multilingual metadata modeling settings, the 
same concept can be referred to as, for instance, cancer du sein in French, 
cáncer de mama in Catalan, or rakovina prsu in Czech. While technologies 
from natural language processing can be harnessed to implement some 
of these semantic (non)equivalences, it is crucial for the metadata librar -
ian to first diagnose and understand the entanglement and manifoldness 
existent in the equivalency mapping.
Third, given the elucidation of terminological entanglement, let us 
now elaborate the notion of ontological entanglement, which refers to 
the necessary existence of a many-to-many mapping between labeled con-
cepts and their ontological commitment. Two interlinked dimensions un-
derlie the above entanglement. First, due to perceptual and subsequent 
terminological entanglement, different communities of library users can 
perceive and label the same entity differently, thereby bootstrapping the 
many-to-many mapping between different entities/concepts and the 
different top-level ontological categories they might potentially be cat-
egorized into. Second, as a consequence of the first reason, different 
communities of library users, unknowingly and implicitly, commit to the 
philosophical doctrine of one of the state-of-the-art top-level ontologies, 
thereby adding a second layer of many-to-many entanglement between 
entities and top-level ontological theories (see, e.g., Gangemi et al. 2002; 
Guizzardi et al. 2022; Smith et al. 2005). The ontological entanglement 
resulting in a multiplicity of representational manifoldness between labeled 
concepts and their top-level ontological characterization, in effect, trans-
lates into application-level implementational entanglements such as the 
management of interoperability and harvesting of metadata in networked 
academic library settings (Taha 2012). To exemplify, in the motivating 
example, let us consider the ontological entanglement in the oncology 
policy library metadata model (Bagchi 2024, 27). Notice that the same 
concept of a “policy document” has been categorized into different onto-
logical categories (Information Object, Artifact, Continuant) by different 
top-level ontologies (DOLCE, UFO, BFO), respectively. Further, each of 
[91.100.61.210]   Project MUSE (2025-11-05 17:26 GMT)
310 library trends/february 2025
these categories can be instantiated for various other labeled concepts, 
for example, textbook (Bagchi 2024, 28) (having a different semantics).
Fourth, with the assumption of ontological entanglement and onto-
logical constraints, let us now elucidate the taxonomical entanglement 
subproblem, which refers to the necessary existence of a many-to-many 
mapping between ontologically enriched concepts and their taxonomic 
classification that would eventually constitute the backbone of a library 
metadata model. Four key parameters, from Ranganathan’s (1967, 1989) 
faceted classification theory, induce representational manifoldness at this 
stage. First, with respect to a concept at a specific level of abstraction in the 
taxonomy, there are always multiple characteristics that can be employed 
to taxonomically specialize that concept into (potentially many) subordi-
nate concepts. Second, the successive application of characteristics across 
the entire depth of taxonomy (with the possibility of multiple classifica-
tory characteristics at each level of abstraction) leads to potentially infi-
nite entangled classifications. Third and fourth, there can also be multiple 
ways in which concepts can be organized horizontally across a specific 
level of taxonomic abstraction (termed arrays in Ranganathan 1967) and 
vertically across a taxonomic path (termed chains in Ranganathan 1967), 
respectively. In the motivating example, the author used ChatGPT 3.5 to 
elicit the LLM response to the prompt requesting the taxonomical choices 
made (Bagchi 2024, 30–34). Note that the human-LLM prompt collabora-
tion, although simplistic, returns two equally probable but different entan-
gled taxonomies for the oncology policy library user community (Bagchi 
2024, 31). It is interesting to observe that in example 1 the taxonomy is 
implicitly suited for a library metadata model on a social health care policy 
perspective, whereas in example 2 the taxonomy is implicitly suited for a 
library metadata model on a governmental health care policy perspective.
Last but not least, with the assumption of taxonomical entanglement, 
let us now elucidate the problem of definitional entanglement, which re-
fers to the necessary existence of a many-to-many mapping between the 
taxonomic concepts and their interrelation and description via proper -
ties. Two key factors magnify representational manifoldness in this final 
stage. First, during the final decision to characterize a property (uncov-
ered at the ontological level) as an object or a data property, there exists 
a many-to-many mapping as the same property can be represented and 
refactored as an object or a data property depending on the purposes and 
goals to be served by the library metadata model. Second, a concept in the 
taxonomy can be interrelated and described via multiple possible com-
binations of sets of object and data properties, again, depending on the 
precise purpose of the final metadata model. In the motivating example, 
the author used ChatGPT 3.5 to elicit the LLM response to the prompt 
requesting the object and data property choices made (Bagchi 2024, 34–
39). For example, the human-LLM collaboration example generated two 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 311
equally probable but different sets of object and data properties implicitly 
suited for the medical students and medical study participants user com-
munity of a medical college library, respectively (Bagchi 2024, 36).
Finally, the aforementioned individual level-by-level representational 
manifoldness is accumulative in nature, and, therefore, there is also an 
overall manifoldness between entities and their taxonomy and defini-
tional characterization. In the motivating example, the author used Chat-
GPT 3.5 to elicit the LLM response to the prompt requesting the overall 
many-to-many mapping between entities, taxonomical hierarchies, and 
property-based characterization (Bagchi 2024, 39–43). For example, even 
within the same macro domain of discourse, cancer, different perceptions 
by the three different communities of library users (cancer specialists, 
oncology policy experts, and medical college professionals) generated 
multiple terminologies, ontological categories, taxonomies, and property 
predications, most of which are not in correspondence with each other. 
Further, as also previously noted in the second section, it might well be the 
case that for an application scenario, there might be no manifoldness in 
perception or in terminology or both (with, e.g., the other entanglements 
still holding). In any case, the conceptual entanglement problem is a ge-
neric characterization inherent and implicit by design in any library meta-
data model and should be adapted as necessary on a case-by-case basis.
Toward Generative AI–Driven Disentangled  
Metadata Modeling
After the elucidation of how the conceptual entanglement problem is in-
herent, by design, at each representation level, let us now describe in de-
tail how a metadata librarian can exploit the conceptual disentanglement 
approach, via generative AI–driven, human-LLM collaboration, to disentangle 
entangled metadata within the framework of an academic library. To that 
end, we have the following:
1. Perceptual disentanglement, referring to the explicit representational 
bijection between entities and their perception as concepts;
2. Terminological disentanglement, referring to the explicit representa-
tional bijection between perceived concepts and the terminology used 
to linguistically label them;
3. Ontological disentanglement, referring to the explicit representational 
bijection between labeled concepts and their ontological commitment;
4. Taxonomical disentanglement, referring to the explicit representational 
bijection between ontologically characterized concepts and their precise 
taxonomy;
5. Definitional disentanglement, referring to the explicit representational 
bijection between the taxonomic concepts and their definition via prop-
erties.
312 library trends/february 2025
In order to exemplify this stratification, the same motivating example of 
the ontology-driven library metadata model for the cancer domain is em-
ployed (Bagchi 2024, 8–43). Notice also the fact that this stratification of 
conceptual disentanglement is in sync with both the stratification of con-
ceptual entanglement and the stratification of representation in metadata 
proposed in the second and the third sections, respectively. The above 
levels are elucidated as follows.
First, let us concentrate on the perceptual disentanglement subap-
proach that advocates, on the part of the metadata librarian (i.e., the mod-
eler), deciding on an explicit one-to-one mapping between entities and their 
perception as concepts. As described and exemplified in the third section, 
even for the same (domain) entities, there is an inherent representational 
manifoldness that entangles the resultant library metadata model. Two 
key factors underlie the disentanglement approach of a metadata librar -
ian at this level. First, the metadata librarian has to generate, via prompt 
engineering (similar to that in the motivating example), an initial charac-
terization of the perception they want to follow in designing the metadata 
model. Notice that the goals and purposes such a model would potentially 
serve are a key influence on the design of prompts at this stage to elicit a 
reasonable response from the LLM. Given an initial record of perception 
generated via the above human-LLM collaboration, the next crucial step 
for the metadata librarian is to employ a combination of several standard 
techniques to validate and consolidate the generated perception depend-
ing on the criticality of the use of the metadata model. To that end, they can 
conduct a lightweight digital ethnographic exercise (Varis 2015) about the 
user community and its perception about a domain. The librarian can also 
employ focus groups (Morgan 1996) and/or one-to-one consultation with 
domain experts (Drabenstott 2003) to better understand a community’s 
viewpoint about entities of a specific domain. Further, independently or in 
addition to the above, the metadata librarian can perform an information 
and data validation exercise wherein they explore real-life information 
and data resources produced by a user community to gauge its percep-
tions about a domain or even, if available, reuse existing conceptual dis-
entanglement documentation (thereby reinforcing the spiral nature of 
the levels). Finally, the above inputs can be consolidated to validate/re-
pair/enrich the initial perception and, hence, facilitate disentangling the 
perceptual entanglement. To exemplify, in the motivating example, the 
metadata librarian, after the perception validation exercise, might choose 
to add a new concept multi-omics workflow and related properties to the 
perception already generated by the human-LLM collaboration for a can-
cer research library user community. Notice also the fact that the initial 
perception generated via the LLM prompting also reduces to a significant 
extent the otherwise laborious exercise of domain analysis on the part of 
the metadata librarian (Hjørland and Albrechtsen 1995).
 metadata modeling / bagchi 313
Second, assuming the representational bijection at the perceptual level, 
let us now focus on terminological disentanglement, which advocates, on 
the part of the metadata librarian, deciding on an explicit one-to-one map-
ping between perceived concepts and the terminology that would com-
pose the disentangled library metadata model. The guiding cardinal rule 
that a metadata librarian can employ for disentanglement at the termi-
nology level can be referred to as the principle of user warrant. It is based 
on the generalized notion of warrant in information science (Lancaster 
1972; Nylund 2020) and can be understood as the principle to assign to 
a perceived concept a linguistically disambiguated and semantically ex-
plicit term that is based on the documented warrant of the (expert) li-
brary users. To that end, each (meta)data concept/property term label 
should embody standard terminological quality, such as having a natural 
language gloss, examples, identifiers, and so on (Miller 1995). There are 
several (combinations of) options that a metadata librarian can exploit 
to achieve representational bijection of terminology. If the user warrant 
is to use relatively commonsense terms to refer to concepts of cancer, for 
example, in an oncology policy library, lexical-semantic resources such 
as WordNet (Miller 1995) might be exploited to achieve the representa-
tional bijection. On the other hand, if the user warrant in a specialized 
cancer research library is to refer to concepts of cancer using scientific 
terms, resources such as specialized glossaries and health care/clinical 
terminological standards (Schulz et al. 2019) can be exploited to achieve 
an explicit one-to-one mapping. Further, in multilingual settings, natural 
language processing resources such as multilingual variations of WordNet 
and WordNet-like resources (Dash et al. 2017; Navigli and Ponzetto 2012; 
Pianta et al. 2002) and/or open multilingual knowledge bases such as 
Wikidata (Vrandečić and Krötzsch 2014) can be exploited to disentangle 
and disambiguate terms.
Third, assuming the representational bijection at the terminological 
level, let us move to the next activity of ontological disentanglement, 
according to which the metadata librarian has to decide on an explicit 
one-to-one mapping between labeled concepts and their ontological com-
mitment. Similar to the disentanglement strategy at the terminological 
level, the general guidance of user warrant is key to uncovering the onto-
logical commitment of library users at this level. To that end, the metadata 
librarian can apply a four-stage approach. First, the librarian can prompt 
an LLM such as ChatGPT 3.5 appropriately (see, for instance, the exam-
ples in the motivating example at Bagchi 2024, 23–29) to bootstrap an 
initial “entangled” version of the alignment of the library metadata model 
with different state-of-the-art top-level ontologies. Second, the librarian 
can reuse the outputs and documentation of focus group interviews, do-
main expert consultation, and/or relevant conceptual disentanglement 
documentation to understand the ontological warrant of the community 
[91.100.61.210]   Project MUSE (2025-11-05 17:26 GMT)
314 library trends/february 2025
of library users they are attending to. Third, the librarian can use the re-
sults of the second step to explicitly choose and enrich the best possible 
ontological fit among the different ontology alignments produced in the 
first step. Finally, the metadata librarian should explicate the ontological 
categories of each individual labeled concept and property that is under 
consideration with respect to the chosen top-level ontology.
Fourth, assuming the representational bijection at the ontological level, 
let us now concentrate on taxonomical disentanglement, which advocates, 
on the part of the metadata librarian, deciding on an explicit one-to-one 
mapping between ontologically characterized concepts and their precise 
taxonomy. Given the general direction from the needs of the library and 
information service(s) that would exploit the final library metadata model, 
the metadata librarian can follow a four-step disentanglement strategy in 
response to the four stages of taxonomical entanglement (see the third 
section of the paper). The solution is grounded in the canons of knowledge 
classification proposed by Ranganathan (1967, 1989) in his faceted classifi-
cation theory. First, the canons of characteristics (Ranganathan 1967), such 
as canons of relevance and ascertainability, should be applied to elimi-
nate manifoldness at the level of selecting a classificatory characteristic 
for specializing concepts at a specific level of abstraction in the taxonomy. 
Second, the canons of succession of characteristics (Ranganathan 1967), such 
as the canon of relevant succession, should be applied to disentangle the 
multiplicity existent in how classificatory characteristics are successively ap-
plied to design the conceptual depth of the taxonomy. Third and fourth, 
the canons of arrays and chains (Ranganathan 1967) should be applied to 
disentangle the manifoldness existent while modeling concepts across a 
specific horizontal level and across a path of the taxonomy, respectively. 
To aid the above exercise, the metadata librarian can also consult and 
reuse relevant state-of-the-art taxonomies if available as open-source code. 
Finally, the above procedure is expected to generate an enriched and dis-
entangled version of one of the many possibilities initially generated via 
human-LLM collaboration, for example, as exemplified in the motivating 
example (Bagchi 2024, 30–34).
Last but not the least, assuming the representational bijection at the 
taxonomical level, let us move to the final activity of definitional disen-
tanglement, according to which the metadata librarian has to decide on 
an explicit one-to-one mapping between the taxonomic concepts and 
their interrelation and description via properties. To that end, the librar -
ian can proceed on a two-step strategy. First, they should make explicit a 
final decision on the exact split of properties into two distinct sets: a set 
of object properties and a set of data properties. This decision is critically 
influenced by the information service applications driven by the warrant 
of a specific community of library users. Given the first step, the next step 
is to make explicit the decisions on exactly how the object properties would 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 315
be exploited to interlink the concepts in the disentangled taxonomy, in 
other words, determining the precise conceptual domain and ranges of 
the object properties. Further, perhaps most importantly, the librarian 
should determine the exact set of data properties that should describe each 
concept in the taxonomy (also factoring in the taxonomic inheritance). 
Together, the above steps can facilitate a representational bijection and, 
thereby, generate the final disentangled ontology-driven library metadata 
model out of the many entangled possibilities initially generated via gen-
erative AI–driven human-LLM collaboration, for example, as exemplified 
in the motivating example (Bagchi 2024, 34–39).
There are three key observations with respect to the aforementioned 
elucidation of the levels of conceptual disentanglement. First, as in the 
second and the third section, it might well be the case that for a spe-
cific application scenario, implementing the conceptual disentanglement 
exercise is relevant only for specific representation levels and not for all 
five levels together. Second, notice that the disentanglement at each of 
the above levels is effectuated by human-LLM collaboration via appropri-
ate prompt engineering. It is definitely the case that in some levels, for 
example, ontological and taxonomical disentanglement, human model-
ers should be more involved than LLMs due to the very conceptual and 
semantics-intensive nature of disentanglement. On the other hand, the 
initial responses generated by LLMs can speed up the bootstrapping of 
modeling metadata by several counts. Notice also the fact that human over-
sight, even if not demanding, is crucial at each level to minimize the effect 
of so-called LLM hallucinations (Chomsky et al. 2023; Rawte et al. 2023). 
Finally, the conceptual disentanglement exercise should be formally docu-
mented as a datasheet (Gebru et al. 2021) for possible future reuse, with all 
the decisions concerning the disentanglement of the manifoldness into 
one-to-one correspondences clearly explicated.
Research Implications for Libraries and Beyond
The deconstruction of a library metadata model as composed of five 
disentangled representation levels is a novel way of thinking about li-
brary metadata and is directly linked to some of the AI, metadata, and 
semantics-based research issues that academic libraries are increasingly 
grappling with. To that end, let us focus on general perspectives relevant 
to related work in library metadata and library knowledge discovery; FAIR 
data and metadata; and AI, generative AI, and academic libraries vis-à-vis 
the conceptual entanglement and disentanglement metadata modeling 
proposal advanced in the current work. Each of the perspectives is indi-
vidually discussed as follows.
Knowledge discovery, according to the highly cited Fayyad et al., can 
be defined as “the non-trivial process of identifying valid, novel, poten-
tially useful and ultimately understandable patterns or knowledge in data” 
316 library trends/february 2025
(1996, 37). Notice that in the quoted definition what is assumed a priori 
is the notion of user warrant-based data modeling and data annotation, 
without which eliciting patterns from such data would be an uphill task. 
In fact, some of the assumptions (alongside many others) were alluded to 
in later works (e.g., Pazzani 2000). Notice that metadata-based data mod-
eling and annotation is key to digital infrastructures such as the digital 
libraries (Borgman 1999) and discovery services (Vaughan 2011) of aca-
demic libraries, which host and expose key assets for the academic library 
user community, especially the community of data science researchers, to 
engage in algorithmic knowledge discovery. To that end, the mainstream 
research in library metadata (see, e.g., Coyle 2015; Dunsire and Willer 
2010, 2011; Peponakis 2013) has overwhelmingly concentrated on devel-
oping metadata schemata (which is key) but has, at best, underconsid-
ered the key spectrum of human factors in modeling metadata. This has 
led to long-standing issues with knowledge discovery in academic librar -
ies (Richardson et al. 2008), metadata crosswalks (Khoo and Hall 2010), 
metadata and data interoperability (Pagano et al. 2013), and so on. More 
recently, the CILIP research report has suggested enhanced emphasis on 
the human and social aspect and termed knowledge discovery a sociotechnical 
process (Cox 2021). The proposal of generative AI–driven conceptual dis-
entanglement in this work across the five representation levels, right from 
(human) perception to the formalization of a library metadata model, can 
contribute as a research catalyst to this underresearched theme. Moreover, 
the level-by-level disentanglement of a library metadata model can form 
the base for developing incremental frameworks and methodologies for 
attenuating the impact of, for example, metadata non-interoperability and 
skewed crosswalks.
The current work is also directly related to the upsurge of research on 
FAIR data (Wilkinson et al. 2016), or data that is Findable, Accessible, In-
teroperable, and Reusable. As stated in its original vision (Wilkinson et al. 
2016), the effort to make data (or, in general, an information resource) 
FAIR involves a dedicated metadata strategy on the part of the implement-
ing entity. Academic libraries and the library metadata community have 
been quick to incorporate the FAIR vision (especially the Findability and 
Accessibility dimensions) and have been successful in the technological 
infrastructure (e.g., data catalogs) backing a stand-alone FAIR implemen-
tation (e.g., see Hettne et al. 2020; Koster and Woutersen-Windhouwer 
2018). However, as the current proposal of conceptual disentanglement 
shows, FAIRification is a multilevel strategy encompassing all five repre-
sentation levels: perception, terminology, ontology, taxonomy, and defini-
tional characterization. This is key, especially for the Interoperability and 
Reusability dimensions, as there can be non-interoperability in each of the 
five representation levels due to representational manifoldness leading to 
non-reusability of digital data and information (thereby also defeating the 
 metadata modeling / bagchi 317
overall purpose of FAIR). Additionally, the above aspect reinforces the 
importance of ontology-driven metadata modeling, as, without an ontol-
ogy structuring and consolidating the (meta)data properties, it is next to 
impossible, as per the current technology toolbox, to achieve interoper -
ability and reusability for both data and ontology (e.g., see Carriero et al. 
2020 and Fernández-López et al. 2019 for related issues and problems). 
Finally, while the conceptual disentanglement framework is innovative in 
its vision of level-by-level FAIRification, it runs the risk of overwhelming 
intellectual work on the part of a metadata librarian.
Finally, on a more abstract note, the current work is reviewed in terms 
of how AI in general and generative AI in particular have impacted aca-
demic librarians, information professionals, and users. The CILIP report 
provides a well-rounded bird’s-eye view as to how AI is going to shape the 
academic library space in the years to come (Cox 2021). The possibilities 
of generative AI applications in academic libraries encompass a rich spec-
trum of information-intensive activities, including, among others, intelli-
gent web and mobile search, sociotechnical infrastructures for knowledge 
discovery, chatbots, marketing and user behavior elicitation, robotics, data 
science community-building, and data stewardship. Notice three dimen-
sions that are key to the sociotechnical toolbox required to conceptualize and 
implement all of the above activities. First, all of the above activities depend 
on the involvement of humans, particularly the warrant of library users but 
also the technical expertise and knowledge of academic librarians and 
other information professionals. Second, all of the above activities also 
depend on the involvement of machines, in other words, computers and 
computing infrastructures, to semiautonomously implement digital infor-
mation services and increase their usage penetration among users. Third, 
all of the above activities crucially depend on metadata, which forms the 
glue between humans (helping them discover and retrieve data, infor -
mation, and knowledge from machines) and machines (to exploit and 
fine-tune user warrant, services, and information discoverability). In this 
context, the current proposal of a conceptual disentanglement strategy for 
modeling library metadata via generative AI–driven human-LLM collabo-
ration contributes to all three dimensions. The strategy involves humans 
(metadata librarians as semantic modelers and users), machines (genera-
tive AI technology [Fui-Hoon Nah et al. 2023; Sætra 2023; Stokel-Walker 
and Van Noorden 2023] in the form of LLMs), and a strategy to model 
disentangled metadata via greater human-AI collaboration.
Conclusion
To summarize, this paper presented a novel generative AI–driven 
human-LLM collaboration approach to model disentangled library meta-
data free from several levels of representational entanglements that can 
otherwise have unintended technological consequences. To that end, the 
[91.100.61.210]   Project MUSE (2025-11-05 17:26 GMT)
318 library trends/february 2025
paper advanced three key contributions. First, it introduced a novel way 
of thinking about library metadata in terms of a composition of five func-
tionally interlinked representation levels from perception to definition 
via properties. Second, it introduced the implicit representational mani-
foldness existent in each of the five levels that cumulatively contributes 
to a conceptually entangled library metadata model. Third, it proposed a 
generative AI–driven human-LLM collaboration-based conceptual disen-
tanglement approach to disentangle the entanglement inherent, level by 
level, in the metadata model, leading to a disentangled metadata model 
that is validated, explanatory, and continually enriched via a spiral pro-
cess. Some of the future research lines in this direction can include a 
new conceptually disentangled interpretation of FAIR (meta)data in li-
braries, elevating the approach to a full-fledged general metadata model-
ing methodology beyond libraries, and a detailed cost-benefit analysis of 
the human-LLM collaboration dimension in conceptual disentanglement. 
The testing of the proposed approach employing open-source state-of-the-
art LLMs other than ChatGPT, a stated limitation in this paper, could also 
be a potential future research study.

Mayukh Bagchi is a postdoctoral researcher specializing in information science and 
artificial intelligence in the Department of Information Engineering and Computer 
Science at the University of Trento, Italy, where he has also been a teaching assistant 
in the Master of AI and Data Science course Knowledge Graph Engineering since 
2020. He is also an affiliated researcher at the Institute for Globally Distributed Open 
Research and Education. He holds a PhD in information engineering and computer 
science and has master’s degrees in both mathematics and information science. He 
has participated in several international AI-based research projects, including JIDEP 
(Horizon Europe Research and Innovation Project), the MIUR-Italy DELPHI Proj-
ect, and the DataScientia Data Space International Research Project. His research 
interests are in interdisciplinary AI, interdisciplinary information science, human-AI 
interaction, philosophy of machine and deep learning, foundations of mathematics, 
and literary epistemology.
